review: While I think this a good idea, it kinda falls flat on it face. There is almost no support for local media, and by almost, I mean it can, but it's not a pleasant experience. In order to stream local media you must use the tab casting feature of the chrome browser. The chrome browser must support the codec you are trying to cast of course, which may limit some users. The videos I tried streaming were H264 with AAC audio. The streaming seemed to work but in order for the video to be full screen on your tv, you must make the video full screen on your computer screen. Oh and I have to mention that the video is limited to the aspect ratio of your computer screen. So if your computer screen is 4:3 and your tv is 16:9, then your widescreen video will be doubly letter boxed. The streaming was also taking up 75-100% processor usage of one of my CPU cores so it appears chrome also has to transcode the video on the fly.IMHO, this product is only really meant for streaming YouTube and Netflix. Since I do not subscribe to Netflix I'm limited to YouTube and there's only so many cat videos before you've really seen them all. So to sum it up, if you want to stream Netflix movies, you probably can't go wrong with this product. If you want to stream anything else, your better off with a Roku.Pros:  Nice and cheap  Good ideaCons:  No real support for local media (chrome tab casting is horrible)  Only real streaming options are YouTube and Netflix.Note to Amazon: Please get it together and provide support for Prime Video... pretty please...
